column1: Lakeville  is the largest city in Dakota County
column3: United States. It is a suburb of Minneapolis-Saint Paul
column4: approximately 20 miles (32 km) south of both downtown Minneapolis and downtown St. Paul.  Lakeville is one of the fastest-growing cities in the Twin Cities area. The U.S. Census Bureau estimated its population to be 67
column5: 317 in 2019.Lakeville lies along Interstate Highway 35. Lakeville first became notable in 1910 when Marion Savage built the Dan Patch Railroad Line to service his Antlers Amusement Park. It later became a flourishing milling center; its agriculture industry is still in operation. While many of Lakeville's workers commute northward to Minneapolis
column7: and more central suburbs like Bloomington
column8: Lakeville has had major industry since the 1960s—including the Airlake Industrial Park
column9: which is served by Airlake Airport

column1: The Sioux people ceded most of southern Minnesota in the Treaty of Traverse des Sioux in 1851. A military road was constructed between Fort Snelling and the southern forts. In 1855
column3: a Saint Paul lumber baron and mail carrier using the road
column4: decided to plat a site halfway between Saint Paul and Saint Peter on a lake he named Prairie Lake. The village was established as Lakeville Township in 1858.  Notoriety came when Colonel Marion Savage expanded his entertainment business into constructing Antlers Amusement Park in 1910. Riding on fame from his success with the Dan Patch racing horse and the popularity of the park
column5: the lake was renamed Lake Marion
column6: and the rail line servicing the park named the Dan Patch Railroad Line.With the mostly rural landscape
column7: early settlers were farmers and this owed to a high percentage of Scandinavians. The other group included Irish
column9: and English who had spread out from Hamilton Landing and Burnsville.  In Karen Miller's diary from 1840 to 1895
column10: Danes reportedly outnumbered Norwegians and travel to Minneapolis was not uncommon for the rural township. Enggren's Grocery was a downtown staple since 1900 until it closed in 2006.The later 20th century followed typically for the outer-ring suburban Twin Cities with official incorporation as the City of Lakeville in 1967. The agriculture industry continued to sustain itself as postwar development did not immediately absorb Lakeville (as well as Interstate 35's later completion date). In the early 21st century
column11: housing and population increases were due to rising land costs in the metropolitan area
column12: causing Lakeville to become a boomtown.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 37.83 square miles (97.98 km2)
column3: of which 36.06 square miles (93.39 km2) is land and 1.77 square miles (4.58 km2) is water. Lakeville includes the Argonne Farms post-World War I settlement project which failed in the early 20th century and was redeveloped in the 21st century into typical suburban retail. Since it was a semi-autonomous village within Lakeville Township before the city's incorporation
column4: it continues to appear today on maps as Argonne.A branch of the Vermillion River flows through Lakeville.  Its headwaters are just west of the city limits in Credit River Township
column5: and it flows eastward across Dakota County until it empties into the Mississippi River at the Wisconsin border.  Much of Lakeville drains into the Vermillion River watershed. North Creek
column6: a major tributary of the Vermillion
column7: begins its flow in northern Lakeville and flows eastward to meet the Vermillion near downtown Farmington just east of Lakeville.  The Vermillion River has been designated as a trout stream by the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources.

column1: Lakeville's climate is classified as warm-summer humid continental with features of a hot-summer humid continental (Köppen Dfa).

column2: Lakeville contains several lakes as well as smaller ponds and wetlands within its borders. The two largest lakes are Lake Marion and Orchard Lake
column3: which are used heavily for recreation such as fishing
column5: and swimming. Smaller named natural lakes include East Lake
column7: Lee Lake and Raven Lake. Valley Lake is a small man-made lake in the northern part of the city.

column2: developed by Maynard Johnson with colleagues at Bloomington-based Hitchcock Industries
column3: is home to as many as 200 companies and an estimated 4
column6: one of the state's largest contiguous industrial parks
column7: has attracted companies ranging from start-ups to large corporations.Airlake Industrial Park was a contrived name – “air” represented the airport that Hitchcock Industries built on the grounds and “lake” signified nearby Lake Marion.Lakeville is served by the Airlake Airport
column8: which has a single runway with an ILS approach.  The airport is managed by the Metropolitan Airports Commission as a reliever facility to draw general aviation traffic. The FAA operates the Minneapolis ARTCC (air route traffic control center) in Farmington
column9: several miles away from the airport.  This center provides traffic control services for Minnesota and surrounding states.

column1: Post Consumer Brands has had its headquarters in Lakeville since 2015.
The city of Lakeville is governed by a five-member city council
column3: although a City Administrator runs day-to-day municipal operations. A professional police force and volunteer fire department protect the city's residents. The city operates a large parks department which includes a senior center
column5: dozens of various neighborhood and community parks
column6: and many miles of multipurpose trails.

column1: Doug Anderson is the mayor of Lakeville. The city is in Minnesota's 2nd congressional district
column2: represented since 2019 by Angie Craig. Lakeville is represented in the Minnesota Senate by District 58 Senator Matt Little
column3: a former Lakeville mayor
column4: and by District 56 Senator Dan Hall. In the Minnesota House
column5: Lakeville is represented by District 58A Representative Jon Koznick

column1: The city is served by three different school districts
column2: whose boundaries were determined while the community was largely agricultural. Today Independent School District 196 ("Rosemount-Apple Valley-Eagan") and Farmington School District 192 serve parts of northern and eastern Lakeville. Most Lakeville households are served by Lakeville Area School District 194. In the fall of 2005
column3: the Lakeville School District opened its second high school
column4: Lakeville South. Some students attend public schools in other school districts chosen by their families under Minnesota's open enrollment statute. Lakeville North was a Blue Ribbon school of excellence in 2009. Each high school has nearly 2
column5: 000 students. There are eight public elementary schools and three public middle schools. Century Middle School students go on to attend Lakeville North
column6: McGuire Middle School students go on to attend Lakeville South
column7: and Kenwood Middle School students attend either school
column8: depending on their neighborhood of residence.

column4: St. Paul and Pacific Railroad's Hastings & Dakota Subdivision went through the center of Lakeville and served various industries. Short-line railroad Progressive Rail is based in Lakeville
column5: and owns the right-of-way of the MN&S Subdivision between Lakeville and Northfield. Between Lakeville and Savage the MN&S Subdivision is owned by Canadian Pacific Railway
column6: but has been out of service since the 1990s. In 2009 Progressive Rail began using a segment of the out-of-service tracks for railcar storage
column7: causing local controversy. The Dan Patch Corridor would go through Lakeville
column8: but has been banned from discussion and funding by the Minnesota State Legislature since 2002. The City of Lakeville opposes public funding of a passenger rail line on the MN&S Subdivision through the community.
